209B31AD893242F8AEB725884315AFB5.description: (C) recognize that inherited traits of individuals are governed in the genetic material found in the genes within chromosomes in the nucleus.

B3982F02A2824345ACE9945D3E7A8F56.description: (B) compare the results of uniform or diverse offspring from asexual or sexual reproduction; and

A350057693A5457ABF6B991ECFB59AE6.description: (A) define heredity as the passage of genetic instructions from one generation to the next generation;

D150797E525641349304508F19EF8BFF.description: (14) Organisms and environments. The student knows that reproduction is a characteristic of living organisms and that the instructions for traits are governed in the genetic material. The student is expected to:

4F6696C94433477DA06A703556DA3959.description: (B) describe and relate responses in organisms that may result from internal stimuli such as wilting in plants and fever or vomiting in animals that allow them to maintain balance.

4425FB2EA8E8471E857DB7A847F923F2.description: (A) investigate how organisms respond to external stimuli found in the environment such as phototropism and fight or flight; and

F0DB17F6EE2A42D8B5B3F4C8C7C7AE7D.description: (13) Organisms and environments. The student knows that a living organism must be able to maintain balance in stable internal conditions in response to external and internal stimuli. The student is expected to:

4846849C4C4D4937B6DB41C7A5451DA2.description: (F) recognize the components of cell theory.

9029462853C545028A3389EB554471BC.description: (E) compare the functions of cell organelles to the functions of an organ system; and

8F0546956201475B9EA34338AB3EF466.description: (D) differentiate between structure and function in plant and animal cell organelles, including cell membrane, cell wall, nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondrion, chloroplast, and vacuole;

52FC2546FCB14CE293037D12ED92FFB3.description: (C) recognize levels of organization in plants and animals, including cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms;

5C9A1DAC76984AEC91D74F91DC726B25.description: (B) identify the main functions of the systems of the human organism, including the circulatory, respiratory, skeletal, muscular, digestive, excretory, reproductive, integumentary, nervous, and endocrine systems;

1C58267DD4A947EAACF501473AB8AA7A.description: (A) investigate and explain how internal structures of organisms have adaptations that allow specific functions such as gills in fish, hollow bones in birds, or xylem in plants;

A89D9CBEC48F4B0493B604F42C829582.description: (12) Organisms and environments. The student knows that living systems at all levels of organization demonstrate the complementary nature of structure and function. The student is expected to:

B76359A9D99542B3B6EDDA0397E98C58.description: (C) identify some changes in genetic traits that have occurred over several generations through natural selection and selective breeding such as the Galapagos Medium Ground Finch (Geospiza fortis) or domestic animals and hybrid plants.

14C548C517C246EC8B3AF2DE7564A291.description: (B) explain variation within a population or species by comparing external features, behaviors, or physiology of organisms that enhance their survival such as migration, hibernation, or storage of food in a bulb; and

6E7799490DAF48ADA11704BF8DC1BE44.description: (A) examine organisms or their structures such as insects or leaves and use dichotomous keys for identification;

F1C3BF1FEAD742569EEDD11278DBB258.description: (11) Organisms and environments. The student knows that populations and species demonstrate variation and inherit many of their unique traits through gradual processes over many generations. The student is expected to:

4BB96946F5A943D18EA5F74659161911.description: (C) observe, record, and describe the role of ecological succession such as in a microhabitat of a garden with weeds.

D70120F14EF643078ACBC45F573C14CA.description: (B) describe how biodiversity contributes to the sustainability of an ecosystem; and

EB0FA43F5CA74B41BB391578CD7E7774.description: (A) observe and describe how different environments, including microhabitats in schoolyards and biomes, support different varieties of organisms;

CA6C085DB7C14BE88267AEB582F0B184.description: (10) Organisms and environments. The student knows that there is a relationship between organisms and the environment. The student is expected to:

7AB5C1BF6C504F43AB144152A94B477F.description: (B) identify the accommodations, considering the characteristics of our solar system, that enabled manned space exploration.

328093F6FD1B48A8A885C24330C32054.description: (A) analyze the characteristics of objects in our solar system that allow life to exist such as the proximity of the Sun, presence of water, and composition of the atmosphere; and

F94F2E8DCD184F4C94D10236AB336656.description: (9) Earth and space. The student knows components of our solar system. The student is expected to:

931433B5912445D188BD82C3C1480CB3.description: (C) model the effects of human activity on groundwater and surface water in a watershed.

BEC7470B5B9B406A9F995861D2D61334.description: (B) analyze the effects of weathering, erosion, and deposition on the environment in ecoregions of Texas; and

11891171AA15440580E6B2947B83B6C4.description: (A) predict and describe how catastrophic events such as floods, hurricanes, or tornadoes impact ecosystems;

D614C878389F410C951882F1803D568D.description: (8) Earth and space. The student knows that natural events and human activity can impact Earth systems. The student is expected to:

7C783FA94042420D9E0393E98A71918B.description: (B) demonstrate and illustrate forces that affect motion in organisms such as emergence of seedlings, turgor pressure, geotropism, and circulation of blood.

FFB3EB517E3D4499A5F346561C2DA8D4.description: (A) illustrate the transformation of energy within an organism such as the transfer from chemical energy to thermal energy; and

AE2DAFA469304874B4D8FA839B797C2F.description: (7) Force, motion, and energy. The student knows that there is a relationship among force, motion, and energy. The student is expected to:

DA0559EF01844995A3D5E2920D2B781F.description: (A) distinguish between physical and chemical changes in matter.

35CF0E061AD142D88D801629C45FF94F.description: (6) Matter and energy. The student knows that matter has physical and chemical properties and can undergo physical and chemical changes. The student is expected to

2D43DE99E71541F7BFEC28AE8F84ED98.description: (B) diagram the flow of energy through living systems, including food chains, food webs, and energy pyramids.

5E42E08ED64349E6A0EE40F502B16699.description: (A) recognize that radiant energy from the Sun is transformed into chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis; and

F801F91FE3DD47DBAB7E38BCCC281F80.description: (5) Matter and energy. The student knows that interactions occur between matter and energy. The student is expected to:

413D392CF7474DE188AF8DD8068B5967.description: (B) use preventative safety equipment, including chemical splash goggles, aprons, and gloves, and be prepared to use emergency safety equipment, including an eye/face wash, a fire blanket, and a fire extinguisher.

F2573991089849EBBF16873D8CF2DB2E.description: (A) use appropriate tools, including life science models, hand lenses, stereoscopes, microscopes, beakers, Petri dishes, microscope slides, graduated cylinders, test tubes, meter sticks, metric rulers, metric tape measures, timing devices, hot plates, balances, thermometers, calculators, water test kits, computers, temperature and pH probes, collecting nets, insect traps, globes, digital cameras, journals/notebooks, and other necessary equipment to collect, record, and analyze information; and

6075BAF9399A492A8AEB03349C433784.description: (4) Science investigation and reasoning. The student knows how to use a variety of tools and safety equipment to conduct science inquiry. The student is expected to:

DE6CFD3FD99847F1B22BF8F60F247334.description: (D) relate the impact of research on scientific thought and society, including the history of science and contributions of scientists as related to the content.

50E3D42F769641C5AA8E78FC50E4F58C.description: (C) identify advantages and limitations of models such as size, scale, properties, and materials; and

51DC78A69CDF4F3F86FF7DF51197C149.description: (B) use models to represent aspects of the natural world such as human body systems and plant and animal cells;

30477B10269044ADB616D77926D51E6B.description: (A) analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

82DE958C3BDD4235A39AA707895C46C3.description: (3) Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions and knows the contributions of relevant scientists. The student is expected to:

68D28E7BC5B64FBEB1D05BF91E3CED79.description: (E) analyze data to formulate reasonable explanations, communicate valid conclusions supported by the data, and predict trends.

1B590F3C22604C2D9DB7C093461D0734.description: (D) construct tables and graphs, using repeated trials and means, to organize data and identify patterns; and

4D8FAEF419354913BC317CAB6B8A2867.description: (C) collect and record data using the International System of Units (SI) and qualitative means such as labeled drawings, writing, and graphic organizers;

E5C37B3B07A14078B48A893A4C0D90BB.description: (B) design and implement experimental investigations by making observations, asking well defined questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and using appropriate equipment and technology;

DD045B0935BB432684395FC979E6475C.description: (A) plan and implement comparative and descriptive investigations by making observations, asking well defined questions, and using appropriate equipment and technology;

BD9A2F9C370A4714BA401BB6EDC4A5E7.description: (2) Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student uses scientific practices during laboratory and field investigations. The student is expected to:

F5CE48FC96B742F6BADFADD4D3703691.description: (B) practice appropriate use and conservation of resources, including disposal, reuse, or recycling of materials.

DB813925D5DE4937953823F235D2D312.description: (A) demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards; and

D788C386048D473BB8F4800CA23104CE.description: (1) Scientific investigation and reasoning. The student, for at least 40% of the instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations following safety procedures and environmentally appropriate and ethical practices. The student is expected to:
